title: I am thinking of filing Ch. 7 Bankrupty but I am not sure I can discharge something. I have a Oregon Labor Board Judgment
question: against me and my now defunct business for $200,000.00. I reside in Riverside County and have for the last 2 years. Can I discharge that in a Ch.7? I couldn't see why now but I am just wanted to make sure.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Employment
answers:
If you want a more detailed response, we need to know what the judgment is for and who it is in favor of.

Rob Taylor
www.affordableattorneysgroup.com

Generally, debts owed to the government are not discahrgeable but there are exceptions. Your best bet would be to contact an experienced BK attorney who can take a look at the paperwork and give you a yes or no answer on dischargeability.

Possible that this Oregon Labor Board judgment may be discharged, however you'll likely need further analysis if you want to know with certainty. For example, absent fraud findings California EDD overpayment claims may still be discharged in bankruptcy (yet, such claim could easily be thought as debt owed to federal/state/etc government).

2 years living in CA meets threshold for filing your case in California/Riverside.

Bottom line: seek help in handling this case from an experienced bankruptcy lawyer.

The very general rule is that debts owed to the federal, state or local governments are NOT dischargeable, however, there are certain exceptions. You need to consult an experienced BK lawyer in your area. Click on the AVVO tab "Find a Lawyer". Many of us offer free consultations. Good luck.

All debts are discharged in any bankruptcy unless the debt falls within one of the exceptions to the bankruptcy code. Is that a tax issue? If a tax, or fine payable to a government then specific laws will apply and I strongly suggest you meet a Bankruptcy Tax Attorney. If not, then normally, unless you are sued by them for fraud in bankruptcy court, it will be discharged. L & I claims in Washington are discharged for example unless the state sues the debtor based on fraud. Good luck.
